channel.title: How does this processor thing work
channel.description:
Hi all,
1: I've recently ordered a pc which has an i7 870 (4x2.93ghz) which is higher than the mid range i7 processors. And I noticed that cod5 requires a 3.0ghz processor, does this mean that my i7 can't play cod5? or will it use the 'turbo boost' technology to do so. Or will it divide it out between the cores.
2: What's actully better to have, single core 3.0ghz processor, or duel core 2.5ghz.
3: What's better to have, Intel quad core 3.0ghz, or i7 2.66ghz.
Thanks

item.title: How does this processor thing work
item.dc:creator: @xEnt xEnt
item.description:
@xEnt wrote:

[quote=“Graham, post:7, topic:361735”][quote author=Fat Cookies link=topic=458003.msg3351797#msg3351797 date=1285409360]
Any core 2 or i3/i5/i7 processor clocked at above 2Ghz will outperform a 3GHz p4 several times over.
[/quote]

It really depends on how you are benchmarking it though. If you are doing a test which is only scheduled on one core of the processor, then the 3ghz P4 would probably outperform the dual/quad core 2ghz processors.[/quote]
nah. clock speeds mean little when comparing CPU’s from different generations.

for example, a 3ghz intel celeron would get fucking raped in a single threaded cpu test against a 1.6ghz i7.

different architectures is what makes the speed difference faster, gigahertz is

An example of the equivalent speed of 1 core on an i7 1000mhz

i7/i5/i3 1000mhz
Core 2 duo 920mhz
Phenom II 850mhz
Phenom 750mhz
Athlon II 720mhz
Athlon 64 570mhz
P4 400mhz
Athlon 350mhz
Celeorn 200mhz
Sempron 200mhz

theres a rough example, a P4 would need to be at about 1.6ghz to match up with a 1ghz i7, and it’s most likely a lot more, like i said this is rough.

Read full topic
item.source: How does this processor thing work

item.title: How does this processor thing work
item.dc:creator: @I_james_I I james I
item.description:
@I_james_I wrote:

[quote=“Graham, post:7, topic:361735”][quote author=Fat Cookies link=topic=458003.msg3351797#msg3351797 date=1285409360]
Any core 2 or i3/i5/i7 processor clocked at above 2Ghz will outperform a 3GHz p4 several times over.
[/quote]

It really depends on how you are benchmarking it though. If you are doing a test which is only scheduled on one core of the processor, then the 3ghz P4 would probably outperform the dual/quad core 2ghz processors.[/quote]

thanks

Read full topic
item.source: How does this processor thing work

item.title: How does this processor thing work
item.dc:creator: @Graham Graham
item.description:
@Graham wrote:

Fat Cookies:

Any core 2 or i3/i5/i7 processor clocked at above 2Ghz will outperform a 3GHz p4 several times over.

It really depends on how you are benchmarking it though. If you are doing a test which is only scheduled on one core of the processor, then the 3ghz P4 would probably outperform the dual/quad core 2ghz processors.

Read full topic
item.source: How does this processor thing work

item.title: How does this processor thing work
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cookies Fat Cookies
item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

Of Course It Will Work Because 2.93 x 4 = 11.72 Gigahertz Of Cpu Power!

On a serious note: I am guessing that the “3GHz processor” in your post is just a p4. They are normally used a benchmark because some people surprisingly still have them. Any core 2 or i3/i5/i7 processor clocked at above 2Ghz will outperform a 3GHz p4 several times over.

Read full topic
item.source: How does this processor thing work

@tL wrote:

I challenge you to a duel… core!

item.title: How does this processor thing work
item.dc:creator: @cumescape cumescape
item.description:
@cumescape wrote:

1: Yes you will be able to play…
2: The Duel Core.
3: More cores & higher clock.

Read full topic
